ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to read academic texts and how to structure longer arguments. It felt like a very big class in developing my writing and reading abilities. I feel much more confident as a writer after going through this class.

Close reading
Writing in an academic conversation
Library research skills
Writing for the public

I learned a lot about staking a claim and conveying the motivation to the audience. Additionally, I learned a ton about overall essay format and how it is the audience or "customer" that determines the value of one's writing. As far as content, I don't even know where to begin. Every single thing we read in this class was illuminating and I feel far more educated today than four months ago.

I learned how to put texts in conversation with each other, and how to manage my time more effectively for a research paper. I also learned how to use the resources of the Yale Library to find good sources.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths were the quality of assignments and readings. I felt like each assignment targeted a different part of writing, which I really appreciated. The readings were a little overwhelming at first, but as the semester progressed I enjoyed them a lot more. Maybe introductions to writing resources could be improved. I did not feel like I was getting timely feedback on my writing, which I would have liked to incorporate that feedback into my later essays. It felt like I was missing mistakes because of this.

Readings were very insightful.
In-class discussions were very interesting. I liked how the idea of chaos was connected to a lot of other topics.
The process of writing the essays was really good. I feel like I became a much better and clearer writer. 

Essays prompts were a bit vague. This was sometimes helpful when it forced me to build my own idea. Other times it made it overly difficult.
I really don't think it can be improved. I thought that, given the COVID-19 circumstances, this class was as engaging and conducive to learning as it could be.

I really liked almost all of the texts that we read, and I thought that the material was very interesting. It was nice that we looked at a variety of disciplines, from science to literature to the environment. Professor Lutz was very knowledgeable, and he could often bring new information into our discussions.
However, the topics sometimes felt a little disconnected. I wish we had done more to relate the environment to the previous topics, and to try to tie everything together at the end. Also, we were behind schedule for much of the semester, which meant that we had less time to discuss many of the texts than had originally been planned.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the reading discussions succeeded, which I was honestly surprised by. I found that the conversations we were having were pretty engaging and I don't have much to critique.
It would have been helpful if the discussions were recorded.

Zoom worked reasonably well for this class. When we went into breakout rooms for discussions or to peer-review papers, there weren't many technical problems.
Unfortunately, our full-class discussions over Zoom weren't as engaging as I'd hoped. There were a lot of pauses, and a few students and Prof. Lutz did most of the talking. Also, we occasionally went into break-out rooms of 2-3 to discuss, but I think that groups of 3-5 would have made for slightly better discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student. It gave me a wonderful base moving forward and I feel much more confident knowing my writing is prepared for further writing courses at Yale. It has fulfilled my expectation as an introductory writing course.

Yes. Despite being just one semester long, the course really improved my writing skills in a lot of areas. As someone interested in science, the topic was fascinating. It was cool how the scientific ideas were connected to literature and nature.
Yes. I think this course does a great job of teaching a student how to read text and how to produce different types of writing.

Especially if you like science, this is a reasonable course to pick. The first half of the course was relatively science-focused, although we also looked at the history of chaos and modern meanings of chaos during that part of the course. The discussions weren't the best, but that probably varies a lot depending on the particular students.
